item.title: Amazon-Exclusive Elden Ring: Nightreign Deluxe Edition Gets Its First Big Discount
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

FromSoft's massively popular--and just plain massive in general--received a co-op spinoff called Elden Ring: Nightreign earlier this year. The game sees groups of 1-3 players teaming up to take on the titanic threats in the new realm of Limgrave. It's been a hit with fans and critics alike, but it's also a big departure from the gameplay of the original Elden Ring. If you've been on the fence, now is a great time to give it a chance, as the Amazon-exclusive Elden Ring: Nightreign Deluxe Edition is discounted to $45 for Big Deals Days. This retailer-exclusive edition offers access to post-launch DLC, a mini digital soundtrack, and a digital art book. It also comes with an exclusive poster of Nightreign's key art in the box. The deal applies to PS5 or Xbox Series X of the game--but it's only available during Prime Big Deal Days on October 7 and 8.

Elden Ring Nightreign

$45 (was $55)

While the combat mechanics in Nightreign are identical to Elden Ring, the overall structure is where you'll see some big differences. Players team up, choose a boss they want to fight, and then set off on an expedition that takes around 35- to 45-minutes to complete. This journey is split across three in-game days, as during the day your team will explore the land of Limveld--an alternate version of Elden Ring's Limgrave--and level up for the fight ahead of them.

Before your squad gets to the main boss, they'll have to take on smaller bosses as the map closes in on them, and on the third day, the grand showdown begins. This core gameplay loop has gone over well with fans, and it has been further polished with post-launch support since then.

"Elden Ring's DNA is ever-present, but Nightreign is also a game of striking subversions: a From Software game that asks you to play it unconventionally, disregarding meticulous exploration, isolation, and measured combat for a cooperative multiplayer game built on speed and aggression. In many ways, it's the antithesis of what people typically come to From Software games for, and yet somehow, someway, this experimental non-sequel is an absolute triumph," Richard Wakeling wrote in GameSpot's Elden Ring: Nightrein review.

If you haven't played it yet, the original Elden Ring game is also on sale. Amazon is offering the PS4 physical edition for $30 (was $40), while the PS5 and Xbox Series X versions have been discounted to $40 (were $50). If you're planning to play on PS5, the PS4 deal is the best one here because Bandai Namco released a free upgrade for it a few years ago. This added an optional performance mode on PS5 that targets 60fps, increased graphical quality, ray tracing, and several other tweaks to Elden Ring's visuals. Elden Ring is considered to be one of From Software's greatest games, and is well worth picking up while it's discounted.

Elden Ring Deals

For a different spin on Elden Ring, check out the official Elden Ring: The Road to the Erdtree manga. This ditches the serious tone of the games, as it gives readers a humorous tour through Limgrave. The illustrations also do an accurate job of recreating the look and feel of the games, and several familiar faces pop up throughout the story.

Elden Ring: The Road to the Erdtree Manga Deals

  • Volume 1 -- $11.39 ($13)
  • Volume 2 -- $11.70 ($13)
  • Volume 3 -- $9.88 ($13)
  • Volume 4 -- $13
  • Volume 5 -- $8.80 ($13)
  • Volume 6 -- $13
  • Volume 7 -- $13 | Releases October 28

There are plenty of other great discounts to take advantage of during Amazon's Prime Big Deals Day sale on October 7 and 8. You can find details on our favorite deals for video games, Blu-rays, and more over on GameSpot's deals hub.

item.title: One Of The Year's Wildest Metroidvanias Is Down To Its Lowest Price Yet
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The Pac-Man spin-off Shadow Labyrinth is getting a nice discount for Prime Big Deal Days. The standard edition on PS5 and Switch is down to just $20 (was $30), while the Secret Edition with its physical collectibles is just $40 (was $60). The sidescrolling metroidvania gives you a chance to see the yellow puck in a whole new light--or shadow, as it were--and since these are the lowest prices we've ever seen for the game, it's a good time to finally check out this wild reimagining of one of gaming's most famous mascots. The discounts will last until the Prime Big Deal Days event ends on October 8.

Shadow Labyrinth Standard Edition

$20 (was $30)

The standard edition of Shadow Labyrinth is available for just $20 on PS5 and Switch. The game hasn't seen many notable price cuts since launching in July, with this edition previously hovering around full price at Amazon on both PS5 and Switch. So if you're interested in the bizarre Pac-Man spin-off, be sure to check out the offers during Prime Big Deal Days.

Shadow Labyrinth Secret Edition

$40 (was $60)

Spend an extra $20 to get a bunch of collectibles. Along with the base game, you'll get a digital art book, digital soundtrack, and the following physical gear:

  • Enamel pin set
  • Iridescent stickers
  • Glow-in-the-dark stickers
  • Booklet case
  • Blacklight keychain
  • Double-sided poster

That's a pretty nice lineup of merch for an extra $20--so if you're a Pac-Man fanatic, it might be a worthwhile upgrade. It's available for PS5 and Switch.

Shadow Labyrinth released on July 18, and while it's earned polarizing reviews from critics due to its ideosyncratic mix of Metroid-style exploratory action and Pac-Man-inspired puzzles, it's no doubt one of the biggest metroidvania-style platformers of recent memory. It's also part of Bandai Namco's infamous "UGSF" crossover universe that includes Galaga, Galaxian, Dig-Dug, Mr. Driller, and even Ace Combat 3 as canon entries--which means fans of classic Bandai Namco series can expect plenty of easter eggs and in-universe references to all those games and more.

Looking for more metroidvanias? You'll find a digital code for Hollow Knight: Silksong on sale at Amazon as well. The highly anticipated game has lived up to the hype--though many find it to be remarkably difficult, thanks to punishing bosses and tricky environmental hazards.

For additional Pac-Man gear, check out the vibrant Arcade1Up Pac-Man Deluxe Arcade Machine. Along with several classic Pac-Man games, it lets you play titles like Dig Dug, Galaga, Mappy, and other retro hits. If you don't have the space for a full cabinet, the tiny Arcade Classics: Pac-Man Edition might be a better fit. It's much cheaper and fits in the palm of your hand, yet still comes with a color screen, classic music, and a tiny control panel.

For more Prime Big Deal Days discounts on video games, anime, and beyond, be sure to check GameSpot's deals hub.

item.title: One Of 2025's Best Co-Op Games, Split Fiction, Is On Sale For Prime Big Deal Days
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

With The Game Awards coming up on December 11, it's time to start getting serious about catching up on your GOTY 2025 backlog. That could be an expensive undertaking at any other time, but thankfully, Prime Big Deal Days is here with plenty of discounted titles to help you achieve that goal. One of those discounted titles is Game Of The Year nominee shoo-in, Split Fiction--normally $50, you can grab physical copies of the critically acclaimed co-op adventure for just $40 on all platforms. Even though it's not the biggest discount ever, we still think it's worth picking up. We did give the game a 10 out of 10, after all.

Split Fiction

$40 (was $50)

In Split Fiction, you and another player will step into the shoes of aspiring writers Zoe and Mio as they journey through dangerous fantasy and sci-fi worlds of their own making. Trapped in this alternate universe by Rader Publishing's experimental simulation tech that steals the ideas of creatives, the two must work together to platform, puzzle-solve, and fight their way back to reality. It's one of GameSpot's highest-rated games of 2025, and it's not a title you should miss (especially now that it's on sale for $10 off the usual price).

And if you're in the mood to pick up some other great co-op games that you can play with a friend, check out some of Hazelight Studios' other titles like It Takes Two, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons, and A Way Out.

Hundreds of other video games are on sale in Amazon's Prime Big Deal Days, along with tons of Blu-rays, graphic novels, and more. Check GameSpot's Deals Hub for a look at some of the most notable offers in the sale--just don't forget that the event only lasts until October 8.

item.title: Bleach: Rebirth Of Souls Gets 50% Discount On PS5 And Xbox
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Bleach is still widely regarded as one of the big three anime of the early 2000s, and recently, it has made a big comeback on TV and in video games. For Amazon Big Deals Days, you can pick up the latest game in the franchise, Bleach: Rebirth of Souls, at its lowest price to date, as it's on sale for $30. That's a 50% discount from its launch price earlier this year, and you can choose between an Xbox Series X or a PS5 physical edition.

Bleach: Rebirth of Souls

$30 (was $60)

Like several other anime franchises given the video game treatment, Bleach: Rebirth of Souls is a 3D arena-fighter. While the genre is admittedly flooded with lackluster efforts--from Naruto to Demon Slayer--the Bleach game does break away from the pack by offering a fighting setup that's built around meaty and complex gameplay systems. The battle system is full of depth and intricate elements, and with stylish character animations, the end result is a slick fighting game that feels rewarding to play once you master it.

  • PS5
  • Xbox Series X

Several other anime series are on sale during this Prime Big Deal Days sale. Fans of Shonen anime will want to check out all the deals on various Dragon Ball anime series and movies, the complete Tokyo Ghoul saga has been marked down by 60% for its 10th anniversary box set, and Jujutsu Kaisen is also down to a new low price. A spiritual successor to Bleach, the second season of the anime is available in two parts, with Part 1 going for $16.49 (Was $40) and the Limited Edition Part 2 box set retailing for $66 (was $100).

For more Prime Big Deal Days discounts, be sure to check GameSpot's Deals Hub.

item.title: Amazon Has Big Deals On GeForce RTX Graphics Cards
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Upgrading your gaming rig during Prime Big Deal Days is a great idea, as over a dozen Nvidia GeForce RTX GPUs are discounted for the shopping holiday. Many of these are available for their lowest price ever, with price cuts of over $100 for select models. This includes premium models capable of playing most modern games without a hiccup and budget-friendly options for those seeking to upgrade an entry-level PC during Amazon's sale, which lasts through October 8.

One of the biggest discounts is for the Asus TUF GeForce RTX 5070 Ti (16GB GDDR7 OC Edition), as it's matching its best price ever of $850 (was $1,000). The RTX 5070 Ti is among the most powerful consumer GPUs available right now, and this OC Edition with 16GB GDDR7 should be more than capable of handling most games when played at high resolutions. If you don't need all the firepower provided by the RTX 5070 Ti, the Asus Prime GeForce RTX 5070 (12GB GDDR7 White OC Edition) is now listed for just $580 (was $710). This card hasn't seen any notable discounts this year, so be sure to check it out during Prime Big Deal Days.

Want to keep your spending under $500? There are plenty of options to consider. The Asus TUF GeForce RTX 5060 (8GB GDDR7 OC Edition) has hit its lowest price of all-time at $340 (was $410), the Asus TUF GeForce RTX 5060 Ti (8GB GDDR7 OC Edition) is a step up at $400 (was $540), and the Gigabyte Aero GeForce RTX 5060 Ti (16GB GDDR7 OC Edition) is just $440 (was $490). That Gigabyte Aero model is also listed for its lowest price ever, and it's probably a great fit for most shoppers. Reviewers have noted that it handles most games in 4K without any issue and is a wonderful value at this new price.

Plenty of other GeForce RTX GPUs are on sale for Prime Big Deal Days, so be sure to shop around and see which one is the best fit for your rig. To make things easier, we've pulled together all our favorite offers from Asus and Gigabyte. After you've browsed these deals, be sure to head over to our Prime Big Deal Days hub for more discounts on PC hardware, video games, Blu-rays, and other categories while Amazon's sale is live from October 7 to 8.

  • Asus Dual Nvidia GeForce RTX 3050 (6GB GDDR6 OC Edition) -- $170 ($200)

item.title: AMD's Ryzen 7 7800X3D CPU Is Over $100 Off For A Limited Time
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

One of the best CPUs for gaming, the AMD Ryzen 7 7800X3D, has just hit its lowest price of the year for Prime Big Deal Days. Long considered the best gaming CPU until the arrival of the Ryzen 7 9800X3D, the older 7800X3D is hard to pass up at just $338 (was $449). The discount will likely only stick around until Big Deal Days end on October 8--so cash in while you can.

AMD Ryzen 7 7800X3D Processor (8-Core, 16-Thread)

$338 was ($449)

The AMD Ryzen 7 7800X3D has a clock speed of 4.2GHz and features AMD 3D V-Cache technology for enhanced performance. Essentially, this technology allows the CPU to retrieve data faster than expected, as it boasts an impressive 96 MB L3 cache (which is extremely noticeable while gaming). It's built on the 5nm Zen 4 architecture, and it's powerful enough for both gaming and work applications like photo editing or intense coding.

The 8-Core, 16-Thread processor is great at multitasking, so you shouldn't have any issues if you decide to stream a TV show or launch into Chrome while waiting for the next round of Counter-Strike. The 7800X3D is widely regarded as one of the best gaming processors on the market, and it's a hard bargain now that it's under $350.

While we're big fans of the AMD Ryzen 7 7800X3D, it's not the only CPU discounted for Prime Big Deal Days. Both AMD and Intel components are on sale--so be sure to shop around to find the best fit for your gaming setup. However, most will likely find the 7800X3D to be the best fit. If you don't mind stretching your budget, you can pick up the Intel Core Ultra 9 Unlocked (24-Core, 24 Thread) for $499 (was $599). Keep in mind that it's not designed for gaming, but folks running intensive video editing applications will find it to be a nice choice.

While the AMD Ryzen 7 7800X3D Processor is quite budget-friendly with this new discount, there are plenty of cheaper options. The AMD Ryzen 5 5500 (6-Core, 12-Thread) is down to $61 (was $159), the AMD Ryzen 9 7900X (12-Core, 24-Thread) is $285 (was $549), and the Intel Core i7-12700K (12-Core, 20 Thread) is $185 (was $510). All three are reasonable choices for gaming, making them worthy alternatives if you're looking to save a few bucks. You'll find a list of AMD and intel CPUs discounted in Amazon's Prime Big Deal Days event below. And don't forget to check GameSpot's Deals Hub page for more of our favorite Prime Big Deal Days discounts on PC hardware, games, anime, and much more.

Best Prime Big Deal Days CPU Discounts

  • AMD Ryzen 5 5500 (6-Core, 12-Thread) -- $61 ($159)
  • AMD Ryzen 7 7800X3D (8-Core, 16-Thread) -- $338 ($449)

  • Intel Core i3-12100 (4-Core, 8-Thread) -- $96 ($155)

item.title: Walmart Deals: Save Big On Gaming Gear, Lego, TVs, Cool Toys, And More
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The October edition of Walmart Deals is live now with promotions on just about every category of product you can think of that the retailer stocks--and Walmart carries just about everything. Although we wish Walmart would pick a distinct name for this sale, that doesn't change the fact that there are a lot of great offers in Walmart Deals. From video game hardware and computing tech to heaps of licensed toys, collectibles, and plushies, Walmart has a wide-ranging selection of notable discounts that are worth checking out.

Walmart Deals: Most Popular

  • Top 100 Walmart Deals
  • Top 100 Toy Deals
  • Top 100 Tech Deals
  • Top 100 Laptop Deals
  • Top 100 TV Deals

Walmart Deals is the biggest sale the retailer has hosted since the July iteration of the same event. The summer sale was a response to Prime Day, while this week's event is squaring off against Amazon Prime Big Deal Days. And like Amazon's other competition, including Target Circle Week and Best Buy Techtober, Walmart Deals runs longer than Amazon's 48-hour Prime Big Deal Days sale (October 7-8). Walmart's week-long sales event ends October 12. But since Amazon matches competitor prices so often, Big Deal Days will still be going strong days after it technically ends.

Walmart's sale pages aren't always the easiest to navigate, and it's not uncommon for products that aren't even discounted to be front and center on Walmart's site. With that in mind, we poked around and put together a list of links that lead to some of the best deals we've spotted so far. It's essentially a Walmart Deals navigation system for GameSpot readers, based on what we see readers most interested in during big sales like this one.

We've also included a short list of our favorite gaming, tech, and toy deals. We'll add to this list throughout the week as deals sell out, so check back for new recommendations in the coming days.

item.title: Nintendo Is Suing A Reddit Moderator For $4.5 Million
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Last year, Nintendo sued James Williams, a moderator for a Switch pirates page on Reddit who posted under the name Archbox. Now, Nintendo has set the damages it wants from the court, and it could leave Williams with a penalty for several million dollars.

Nintendo's legal complaint has been posted online (via Oatmeal Dome), and it's asking for $4.5 million because it contends that Williams operated multiple Switch piracy sites, sold hardware hacks, and offered modified Switch consoles with pirated games. It also alleges that he refused to comply when the company sent him a cease-and-desist order. The complaint notes that Williams stopped acknowledging Nintendo's requests, which led to the lawsuit against him.

Last year, a separate report revealed how Nintendo played detective to identify Williams as the person behind the Archbox Reddit account. Williams' allegedly shared personal details online that helped narrow the search, and he also sent in his Switch to Nintendo for repairs. Nintendo was granted a default judgement against Williams because he didn't plead his case in court before the scheduled deadlines.

In 2024, Nintendo's lawsuit successfully shut down Switch emulator Yuzu and 3DS emulator Citra. Nintendo has yet to file a lawsuit against OpenAI's new Sora 2, which is filled with AI Mario And Pikachu videos that appear to have been created without permission. Nintendo is currently in a legal battle against Palworld developer Pocketpair. Nintendo was also recently granted a patent that may make it difficult for any future Pokemon-inspired games to be released.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Shovel Knight Dev's Next Game Mina The Hollower Delayed, But Not For Long
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The follow-up to Yacht Club's indie hit Shovel Knight will have to wait a little longer, as the studio has announced that Mina the Hollower will be delayed out of its previously announced Halloween release date. While Yacht Club said this delay will be a short one, it isn't prepared to nail down an exact date just yet.

"This week, our team made a tough decision: we decided to delay Mina the Hollower," the team wrote on its official site. "The entire crew has been working tirelessly day and night to finish development for release on October 31, but we’re just not quite there yet. This isn’t a major delay, it’s just a stretch of time to apply some final polish and balancing to make the game truly shine."

Though the delay is short, though, Yacht Club said it doesn't want to announce a new release date until it's submitted to all platforms. In the meantime, it's working on finalizing design, art, and sound, game balancing, localization, and testing. And eating cheese.

"Our goal is to make sure our development team has the time and resources to deliver an incredible adventure and we will be giving you just that," the studio said.

Mina the Hollower is Yacht Club's first original franchise after the breakout success of Shovel Knight in 2014. The studio has been busy in the meantime, though, creating loads of extra DLC campaigns for Shovel Knight, as well as developing and publishing spin-offs like Shovel Knight Showdown and Shovel Knight: Pocket Dungeon.

Mina the Hollower is inspired by the classic top-down Zelda games, with an art style that pays homage to that color palette as well. It stars a little mouse in a kingdom of animals, and as the name implies, she can burrow underground to solve puzzles and surprise enemies.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
